importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication, indicating when the public learned about Daniel Naroditsky's death.
The year Daniel Naroditsky won the Under 12 World Championship, marking a pivotal early achievement in his chess career.
The year Daniel Naroditsky graduated with a bachelor's degree in history from Stanford University.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The time period during which Daniel Naroditsky achieved major milestones in chess, from winning the Under 12 world championship to earning his degree and rising in the global rankings.
The recent period in which Naroditsky was active in livestreaming and competitive blitz chess, culminating in his U.S. National Blitz Championship win in August 2025.

keyTakeAways: Daniel Naroditsky, a U.S. chess grandmaster, died at age 29, leaving behind a legacy of promoting chess through accessible and educational livestreams.
Naroditsky won the Under 12 World Championship in 2007 and became a grandmaster at age 18, demonstrating early prodigious talent.
He maintained a top-25 ranking in blitz chess throughout his adult career and recently won the U.S. National Blitz Championship in August 2025.
Naroditsky was a major figure in popularizing chess via livestreaming on platforms like YouTube and Twitch, reaching thousands of viewers and helping to educate newcomers to the game.
He was known for his passion for education and his engaging, educational style of commentary, earning praise from fellow grandmasters like Hikaru Nakamura and Benjamin Bok.

Naroditsky was born in San Mateo County, California, to Jewish immigrant parents from Ukraine and Azerbaijan, and studied history at Stanford University before moving to Charlotte, North Carolina, to coach junior players.
The Charlotte Chess Center publicly mourned his death, calling him a 'talented chess player, educator, and beloved member of the chess community.'

summaryOfNewsArticle: Daniel Naroditsky, an American chess grandmaster born in San Mateo County, California, to Jewish immigrant parents from Ukraine and Azerbaijan, died at age 29. A child prodigy who won the Under 12 World Championship in 2007 and became a grandmaster at 18, Naroditsky maintained a top-25 ranking in blitz chess throughout his adult career and recently won the U.S. National Blitz Championship in August 2025. He gained widespread popularity by livestreaming chess matches and providing educational commentary on platforms like YouTube and Twitch, helping to introduce the sport to a global audience. Fellow grandmasters, including Hikaru Nakamura and Benjamin Bok, praised his passion for teaching and communication. Naroditsky coached junior players at the Charlotte Chess Center in North Carolina, where he was a beloved and influential figure. His death has prompted deep mourning from the international chess community, with the center and peers recognizing him as a talented player, educator, and mentor who brought joy and inspiration to countless fans.
title: American chess grandmaster Daniel Naroditsky dies at 29
